subject: RE: [junit] Support for JUnit
msgSnippet: Just go to http://groups.yahoo.com/group/extremeprogramming and click on Subscribe somewhere on the right hand side of the page.  You may need to create a
messageBody:
Just go to http://groups.yahoo.com/group/extremeprogramming and click on
'Subscribe' somewhere on the right hand side of the page. You may need to
create a yahoo account if you don't already have one.

-Jason

> -----Original Message-----
> From: qionghua yang [mailto:qhyang@...]
> Sent: Wednesday, July 11, 2001 3:04 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Support for JUnit
>
>
> Hi Rainsberger,
> I am a newbie here. Could you please tell me how can I
> be added into the
> XP mailing lists. I have checked the
> www.xprogramming.org and could not
> find one. Thanks!
>
> qionghua
>
>
> >From: rainsber@...
> >Reply-To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> >To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> >Subject: Re: [junit] Support for JUnit
> >Date: Wed, 11 Jul 2001 11:24:44 -0400
> >
> >Too true. No amount of UI, documentation and fancy API
> can tell you "when"
> >and "why" to test. For that, you need either experience
> or a coach. I think
> >this mailing list provides the necessary coaching. The
> XP mailing lists
> >provide even more.
> >
> >J. B. Rainsberger <rainsber@...>
> >Commerce Suite Accelerator: Rule Services, IBM Toronto Lab
> >8200 Warden Av, Office A3-735 [A3/FNB/8200/MKM]
> >Markham ON L6G 1C7
> >905 413-2501 (969-2501)
> >
> >
> >Jim Cheesman <jchees@...> on 07/11/2001 10:59:10
> >
> >Please respond to junit@yahoogroups.com
> >
> >To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> >cc:
> >Subject: Re: [junit] Support for JUnit
> >
> >
> >
> >At 04:40 PM 11/07/01, you wrote:
> > >I am not an agent of JUnit. What follows is my opinion
> and nothing more.
> > >
> > >JUnit is so simple that there is no need for support
> of any kind, beyond
> > >this mailing list. I hope that JUnit always stays as
> simple as it is now,
> > >so that it never needs support.
> > >
> > >That's the beauty of JUnit: its simplicity.
> >
> >
> >I'm inclined to agree... up to a point ;) Using JUnit is
> a matter of
> >learning a new API - I don't think that support per se
> is really needed, at
> >most maybe some classes on how to set up the tests.
> >
> >Why up to a point? Because the api is only the "how" of
> testing - learning
> >the "when" and "why" is another matter...
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >--
> >
> > * Jim Cheesman *
> > Trabajo:
> >jchees@... - (34)(91) 724 9200 x 2360
> > Prejudiced
> >people are all alike.
